moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5
comment: Makes easier the defense for Black. Better was 5.Nf3.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6
1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5
comment: Forced.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5
comment: There was no choice.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5
1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5
comment:
Mikenas: "Alekhine looked nervous. It was necessary to
realize the wrong opening strategy and try to keep equality with 14.Nc3."

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7
comment:
(!) Now Black, gaining a tempo, can double his forces on the "d"
file and create "hidden" threats.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2
comment:
Mikenas again:" A GM
with a world reputation should not fall in a trap. I think it is not necessary
to point out that white is already in bad shape. It is the effect of the bad
omen?"

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2 Nef4
comment:
(!) "I realized that, after this move, Alekhine had a jolt.
Probably such a move was unexpected. Trying to calm down, arranged his glasses,
and thought for 40 minutes before making his move." Mikenas, in his article,
confessed that he had not calculated in depth the consequences of his Knight
sacrifice.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2 Nef4 17. Qc4
comment:
After this move Black has an opportunity to seriously
weaken opponent's castling.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2 Nef4 17. Qc4 Nxg2 18. Kxg2 Qh3+ 19. Kh1 Be6
comment: (!) Threatens 20...Ne3.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2 Nef4 17. Qc4 Nxg2 18. Kxg2 Qh3+ 19. Kh1 Be6 20. Qe4 Bf5 21. Qe2 Qg4
comment: (!) Threatens 22...Nf4 23.gxf4 Rxd2

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2 Nef4 17. Qc4 Nxg2 18. Kxg2 Qh3+ 19. Kh1 Be6 20. Qe4 Bf5 21. Qe2 Qg4 22. Rfe1 Rac8 23. Ne4
comment:
Only nervousnes
s can explain such a mistake by Alekhine. It was necessary to defend with 23.
Rac1. Witnesses tell that right in that moment a waiter brought some coffee to
Alekhine. He thanked the waiter and still looking at the chessboard put a
piece of sugar in the coffee cup. Only at the last moment he realized that it
was not a piece of sugar but ... a white pawn. While he realized his mistake,
he got upset, said something, pushed the cup away and .... coffee spilled out
of the cup. Mikenas too noticed his opponent apparent nervousness, and perhaps
distracted by this fact he immediately took the Knight.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2 Nef4 17. Qc4 Nxg2 18. Kxg2 Qh3+ 19. Kh1 Be6 20. Qe4 Bf5 21. Qe2 Qg4 22. Rfe1 Rac8 23. Ne4 Bxe4
comment:
After this
move Mikenas realized that strangely his opponent was smiling. With a
trembling hand Alekhine pointed to the c2 square and said:" Young man, if you
played Rc2 you had won at once." Mikenas confesses: "Only after Alekhine's
words I realized that I had such an opportunity."

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2 Nef4 17. Qc4 Nxg2 18. Kxg2 Qh3+ 19. Kh1 Be6 20. Qe4 Bf5 21. Qe2 Qg4 22. Rfe1 Rac8 23. Ne4 Bxe4 24. Qxe4 Qxe4 25. Rxe4 Rc2 26. Bd4 Rc4
comment:
Annotations by
Mikenas, in this game, are many and generous: "In my analysis before the 23rd
move, I had reached this position in my mind and indeed it looked promising.
This explains, maybe, why I overlooked 23...Rc2 with the possibility of a
beautiful win and the opportunity to take ... a beauty prize."

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2 Nef4 17. Qc4 Nxg2 18. Kxg2 Qh3+ 19. Kh1 Be6 20. Qe4 Bf5 21. Qe2 Qg4 22. Rfe1 Rac8 23. Ne4 Bxe4 24. Qxe4 Qxe4 25. Rxe4 Rc2 26. Bd4 Rc4 27. Re2 g5
comment:
(!) Trying to fix the castle pawns on the dark squares. A very important
strategical motive.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2 Nef4 17. Qc4 Nxg2 18. Kxg2 Qh3+ 19. Kh1 Be6 20. Qe4 Bf5 21. Qe2 Qg4 22. Rfe1 Rac8 23. Ne4 Bxe4 24. Qxe4 Qxe4 25. Rxe4 Rc2 26. Bd4 Rc4 27. Re2 g5 28. h3 h5 29. Bb2 g4 30. hxg4 hxg4 31. Nd4 e6 32. Re4
comment:
In a difficult situation Alekhine succeded to find some chances of salvation.
Now he threatens both 33.Rxg4 and 33.Nxe6.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2 Nef4 17. Rxg4 Kf8
comment: Inaccurate. The right move was 34...Rd5! Now the fight is on.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2 Nef4 17. Bxc3 Rxc3 34. Rxg4 Kf8 35. Re4 Rd5 36. Ne2 Rc2 37. f4 Rdd2 38. Re1
comment:
Even if White is a pawn up, he is not
in good shape. The two black Rooks on the second rank are a deadly danger.
Next aim for black: put his own Bishop in action.

Rxb7 exf4 49. gxf4
comment:
White's attack has lost
part of his strengt. Now it is up to Mikenas to find the conclusion.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d5 5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Nf3 O-O 7. O-O c5 8. e4 Nf6 9. e5 Nd5 10. dxc5 Na6 11. a3 Nxc5 12. b4 Ne6 13. Bb2 a5 14. b5 Qd7 15. Qe2 Rd8 16. Nbd2 Nef4 17. Rxb7 exf4 49. gxf4 Rg2+ 50. Kf3 Rgf2+ 51. Ke3 Rae2+ 52. Kd3 Re6 53. Rc6 Rf3+ 54. Kd4 Rxf4+ 55. Kd5 Rf5+ 56. Kd4 Rxc6 57. bxc6 Ke6 58. Rb5 Rxb5 59. axb5 Kd6 60. Kc4 Kc7 61. Kb3 Kb6 62. Kc4 Bd6 63. Kd5 Bc7
comment:
Mikenas:" I always had a kind relationship with
Alekhine but, after this game, the Champion avoided talking to me for three
days. The great chessplayer don't like to lose...".  This is a truth for every
chessplayer, even the titleless ones; indeed even for the chessplayer who play
once a week at a cafe!
